Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Protein Arginine Methylation in the Co-transcriptional Recruitment of pre-mRNA Splicing Factors

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit. In eukaryotes, proper gene expression is vital for the control of many cellular processes and responses. The initial step of gene expression requires the copying of the DNA into an intermediate molecule called the RNA via a process called transcription. During transcription, the unfinished RNA must simultaneously be processed by a multitude of specific proteins, including the splicing factors (which are members of a macromolecular protein complex called the spliceosome), in order to generate a final, finished product. As the RNA molecules are made and processed, they are packaged into a complex called messenger ribonucleoprotein (mRNP) particle and once finished, the entire mRNP is then exported out of the cell nucleus. To achieve and coordinate the coupling of these biological processes, the RNA-binding proteins must be recruited to the RNA in a very precise order during transcription. As a way to expand or to regulate the function of a protein, many RNA-binding proteins are modified chemically by specific enzymes. Arginine methylation is one such type of chemical modification that is found on many RNA binding proteins, and this modification is catalyzed by a family of enzymes known as protein arginine methyltransferases (PRMT). This enzyme family has been identified in species ranging from the budding yeast to humans, with the most conserved member of this family being PRMT1. In the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, it was established that yeast PRMT1 (termed Hmt1) plays a functional role in promoting the recruitment of splicing factors during transcription, which is vital to mRNP formation. The goals of this project are to examine the mechanisms by which protein arginine methylation modulates the co-transcriptional recruitment of splicing factors in the simple eukaryotic model organism Saccharomyces cerevisiae. A combination of molecular biology, biochemistry, proteomic, and genomic methodologies will be used. Because of the high conservation between yeast Hmt1 and its homologs in higher eukaryotes, the information obtained from this project will provide insights that will likely be applicable to those organisms.

Broader Impacts. This project will provide opportunities to train graduate students and post-doctoral fellows at University at Buffalo, which is a very diverse campus. The graduate students will receive training in the areas of molecular biology, biochemistry, and genomics. Undergraduate students will also be recruited to take part in various aspects of this project and these recruits will include members of the New York Collegiate Science & Technology Entry (CSTEP) program, an enrichment program for students who are economically disadvantaged or historically underrepresented. Since the project involves the use of molecular biology with genomics and computational analysis, the students will benefit from crossdisciplinary training. Travel funds will be used to allow students to present talks and posters at national scientific meetings. Findings from this work will be incorporated into an Advanced Molecular Biology laboratory course offered to the more senior undergraduates at University at Buffalo. The microarray data generated from this project will be made available to the public.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT:

 

In eukaryotes, proper gene expression is vital for the control of many cellular processes and responses.  The initial step of gene expression requires the copying of the DNA into an intermediate molecule called the RNA via a process called transcription.  During transcription, the unfinished RNA must simultaneously be processed by a multitude of specific proteins, including the splicing factors (which are members of a macromolecular protein complex called the spliceosome), in order to generate a final, finished product.  As the RNA molecules are made and processed, they are packaged into a complex called messenger ribonucleoprotein (mRNP) particle and once finished, the entire mRNP is then exported out of the cell nucleus.  To achieve and coordinate the coupling of these biological processes, the RNA-binding proteins must be recruited to the RNA in a very precise order during transcription.  As a way to expand or to regulate the function of a protein, many RNA-binding proteins are modified chemically by specific enzymes.  Arginine methylation is one such type of chemical modification that is found on many RNA-binding proteins, and this modification is catalyzed by a family of enzymes known as protein arginine methyltransferases (PRMT).  This enzyme family has been identified in species ranging from the budding yeast to humans, with the most conserved member of this family being PRMT1.  In the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, it was established that yeast PRMT1 (termed Hmt1) plays a functional role in promoting the recruitment of splicing factors during transcription, which is vital to mRNP formation.  The goals of this project was to examine the mechanisms by which protein arginine methylation modulates the co-transcriptional recruitment of splicing factors in the simple eukaryotic model organism Saccharomyces cerevisiae.  A combination of molecular biology, biochemistry, proteomic, and genomic methodologies was used.  We have identified an important role for Hmt1-mediated methylation of the SR-like/hnRNP-like protein called Npl3.  Importantly, Npl3 methylation is critical for the recruitment of splicing factors required during the early stages of the spliceosome assembly.  Furthermore, we obtained evidence that Hmt1 contributes to efficient splicing of pre-mRNAs that contain non-consensus 5’ splice site and branch site via methylating Npl3.  The impact by which Hmt1 facilitates efficient splicing of pre-mRNAs containing these non-consensus sites is more pronounced in cold temperature, implying a potential role for Hmt1 in the modulation of pre-mRNA splicing during stress.  In addition, we have identified additional Hmt1 substrate that plays a role in the formation of the commitment complex during the spliceosome assembly, in addition to the U1 snRNP component Snp1 that we have previously identified.  It would be of great interest to understand the functional consequences of arginine methylation of these splicing factors on the process of pre-mRNA splicing, as the knowledge of how post-translational modifications regulate pre-mRNA splicing remains sparse.         

 

BROADER IMPACTS:

 

This project provided training opportunities undergraduates, graduate students, and post-doctoral fellows at University at Buffalo.  The graduate students (4 PhD students) have received training in the areas of molecular biology, biochemistry, proteomics, and genomics.  This project also provided 8 undergraduate students opportunities to contribute in various aspects.  These undergraduates include members of the New York Collegiate Science & Technology Entry (CSTEP) program, an enrichment program for students who are economically disadvantaged or historically underrepresented.  The students that participated in this project benefitted from cross-disciplinary training because the project involves the use of molecular biology with genomics and computational analysis.  Travel funds allowed the graduate students involved in this project to present talks and posters at national scientific meetings such as the annual meeting of the RNA Society and the FASEB Meeting on Biological Methylation.  Finally, findings from this work have been incorporated into an Advanced Molecular Biology laboratory course offered to the senior undergraduates at University at Buffalo.  All of the genomic data generated from this project were made available to the public.
